Message.Title: The dividend gambit
Message.Msg: Paul and crew knew that bad news was coming and wanted to lay down covering fire for his friends and family to dump INTC before the shoe dropped. Come on fools, who declares a dividend then wanrs a few weeks later? GS warned what was coming a couple of months ago, remember? After Paul's good friends and neighbors are gonners, down goes the recently announced dividend along with whatever profits-if you have any-and Paul cashes out with a $35,000,000.00 parachute. Get wise to these guys. Sell your positions and go short before Paul & freiends.

Message.Title: Instant computing
Message.Msg: Smartphones have gotten users addicted to instantly accessing online information. The future belongs to gadgets that you can carry with you all day and have available to access whenever you feel like. This trend suggests people will start using their desktops/laptops (and even their tablets) less because they're not instantly available. As the product matures, the smartphone can start providing all the uses that the desktop used to provide completely obliviating the need for less portable alternatives. This is why it's important for Intel to make a play at smartphones even if they are a smaller player at the beginning.

Topic.Title: Instant computing

Message.Msg: The only reason a smartphone is used as a primary gadget is because they can't afford to pay for a smartphone with data package and a tablet or laptop device with internet service. If they pick one they'll take the phone and make do. They use the computer at work or school.

Topic.Title: Down another 5 cents by days end today...

Message.Msg: There has not been any "half dollar strike" options issued by the option market maker for Intel in the last several years. For the Friday WEEKLY option expiration, in addition to the regular strike prices, there are NEW strike values of $16.50, $17.50, $18.50, $19.50, $20.50, $21.50, $22.50, $23.50, $24.50 and $25.50. The new strike prices will help the option market maker cope with the option volume that should be generated by those looking for surprises in Intel earnings or forecast. I expect a lot of option volume near the trading prices in both the put and call options. I expect Intel to end the day at $21.50, $21.75 or $21.25 in that order but on a 25 cent boundary.

Message.Title: Short Risk Skyrockets as Retail Sales Rise
Message.Msg: Shorts and Wall Street have made no secret about pricing Intel as if we are headed squarely into a world-wide depression. But the smoke and mirrors around this assertion are rapidly disappearing in the midst of more and more positive economic news. On top of good housing reports, improvements in employment and sharply better consumer sentiment we now have reports of rising retail sales. Bottom line: There is no basis for the underlying premise that shorts priced in eight times. Shorts have priced Intel as if the world were going to end this week. Tomorrow we will find out it's not going to end this week and that in fact the outlook is improving day by day...

Message.Title: Is this what Wallus means by high speed trading?
Message.Msg: Intel was over 29 in early May of this year. It is now under 22. I had no position in Intel between May and a week ago. I started buying at 22 and added shares at 21.50. Perhaps this will turn out to be a mistake, but if so, I will not be blaming high speed trading for it. The decision to buy was entirely mine, as will be the decision to sell when the time comes, and I had months to watch the situation unfold despite the fact that HFT accounts for the majority of daily transactions in the stock market. Could it be that looking for scapegoats is the endeavor of fools? Could that be the problem Wallus? Perhaps making money in the stock market requires buying at X and selling at Y with Y X (or, equivalently, shorting at Y and covering at X), and all the posting of articles and pumping in the world is merely a waste of time?

Topic.Title: $$$...Analysis: As PC era fades, good times may be over at Intel

Message.Msg: There are a lot of things that could impact Intel. Most will impact other countries too. If you look at the YCHARTS chart of Intel REVENUE TTM it shows a stead up line which doubled during the last 10 years. Rule of 75 suggests that was an average of 7.5% during the last 10 years. Even across the collapse. The Intel stock price (as driven by the analysts) over the past 10 years has forecast SIX of the last TWO Intel downturns. 8-) Intel operates within the economic RIVER or TIDES or put your analogy here .... and that will influence Intel operations substantially. My observations are that Haswell silicon based systems are being deployed at SW and HW OEMs today. I expect that the Intel 16-inch guns have been directed at low power operation and Haswell will make a big differnce. Intel 22nm yield is so high they have an extra fab that can be mothballed or diverted or deployed to build other parts. 4% seems low and the numbers have been questioned by Intel. Intel numbers have been questioned by the analysts. Reports are mixed but generally above the pessamistic targes. The key will be top line growth. 20% .... no. 10% .... more likely 4% .... unlikely

Topic.Title: Shorts being sqeeeeeeeezed !!@ Go Intel up over 1%

Message.Msg: I was responding to bull_no_bear and his statement that I did not believe a 30 cent move was a short squeeze. It is just not a squeeze. If he wants to call it one, that is fine. I presented my reasons for my thinking and I got a rude pre-teen insult response. I do not take pleasure when others suffer. I DO have a low opinion of those who take pleasure when others suffer. I reserve my lowest opinion for those who attempt to cause suffering for their own pleasure or gain. I simply do not believe that the short ratio is high enough in Intel shares to cause a "short squeeze". You and bull_no_bear disagree and that is OK. Why do you think it is a short squeeze? QUESTION: If you believe that there is a large short position, how many of those short shares are represented by the NET ASSET VALUE of the SHORT QQQQ ETF (PSQ)? In other words, this SHORT ETF has to actually short the shares. How many shares of the short interest in Intel are represented by the PSQ? I suspect that someone who BOUGHT PSQ to take a negative QQQQ position does not care about a 30 cent move in INTC.

Message.Title: Wow, a common sense article about Intel today
Message.Msg: Intel Corp (NASDAQ: INTC) is the market leader for processors. I have been an Intel fan since the first Pentium processor. It is still a leader in the PC market, even if the PC market is currently hurting. Maybe the release of Windows 8 can help. First, Intel has a 4.8% dividend yield. That is massive in the tech industry. Technology companies think they can avoid giving dividends as long as they stay on the cutting edge. Most of the companies are mistaken, and recently there has been a shift among the most mature companies to pay dividends. Usually they leave something to be desired. Intel's is extremely high, comparatively. The hit Intel has taken is due to macroeconomic circumstances beyond its control. The company itself seems to be doing very well. It has a lot of cash on hand. I am sure some of its cash is used to fund their venture capital arm, which will keep them innovating into the future. The companies do not need to be successful, but just need to create something that can have value. If Intel sees the value the company can be scooped up, and Intel can use its own distribution channels to make sales. I always like companies that fund innovation outside. I know it has become very common, but I love venture capital as a driver of innovation. The rest of Intel's business looks very strong. A 20% profit margin is great, especially considering Intel is not pure software, but actually does manufacturing. Debt is low compared to assets, but not cash. I would not make too much of that. I see no serious red flags in Intel's business. There might be some demand slumps, but if Intel can cut down on costs, profits can be maintained. Over the last 3 years the share price has been pretty flat; 7% over 3 years is not that great. With the dividend, sitting and waiting is a lucrative prospect. There is no reason Intel should not rise with economic recover, and if it enters more fully into the smart phone market.

Message.Title: Motorola Razr i Intel phone headed for China via China Mobile
Message.Msg: Announced in September as Motorola’s first Intel-powered smartphone, the RAZR i has been released in the UK last week. Motorola officially said the handset would be also launched in other European countries, as well as in Latin America. And now we’re seeing that a redesigned version of it is headed to China. The China-bound Intel smartphone isn’t called Razr i, but MT788. It comes with a remodeled case (there’s no Kevlar fiber on the back), and China Mobile-specific TD-SCDMA connectivity. Other than that, it seems to be identical to the Razr i, featuring a 4.3 inch qHD display, 2GHz Atom processor, 1GB of RAM, 8MP rear camera, and Android 4.0 Ice Cream Sandwich. Check out article by Florin on Unwired View.

Message.Title: Intel's stock price aint gonna collapse under 20 and never recover
Message.Msg: That's just absolutely idiotic. I'm sick of hearing it. If the stock price does go way down temporarily, Intel will buyback a big chunk of the company and increase the EPS dramatically, which will increase the stock price. Ivy Bridge ramped faster than ANY OTHER PRODUCT Intel has ever had.........if that doesn't show you what the demand will be like as they keep shrinking the chips, then you need to have your head checked.

Topic.Title: Intel's stock price aint gonna collapse under 20 and never recover

Message.Msg: Intel will make so much money on Haswell that it will be hard to count it all. They plan on shipping TWICE as many Haswell chips in 1H 2013 than they did Ivy Bridge. Twice as many !! _________________________________________________________ According to some internal info, Intel plans to ramp up Haswell at a much faster pace than Ivy Bridge. It will probably launch the complete portfolio at once, which is not the case with Ivy Bridge, which will first come in quad-core flavor, followed up by dual-cores. The transition to 22nm is not easy and this is why Intel is launching quad-cores and following up with dual-cores. Sometime in 1H 2013, or March to June as it's currently planned, Intel will master 22nm production and should not have the same issues. This means that Core i7, Core i5, Core i3 Haswell chips could launch at the same time. Intel plans to ships almost twice as many Haswell chips in 1H 2013 than it plans to ship Ivy Bridge CPUs in 1H 2012. Intel will still have manufacturing advantage over the rest of the world that now includes AMD, as well as the ARM alliance that will have tough transitioning from 28nm to 22nm. This will be Intel's key advantage in the future that will probably lead them to make some good mobile phone and tablet chips as well. They won't give up without a fight.

Topic.Title: WE DESERVE BETTER LEADER. OBAMA FAILED.

Message.Msg: Coburn's 'Waste Book' details $19 billion in eye-opening government expenses Published October 15, 2012 What do robotic squirrels, menus for Martian meals and a musical about climate change have in common? They've all been made possible with taxpayer assistance, according to the latest survey of government waste put out by Sen. Tom Coburn, R-Okla. Known simply as the Waste Book, the report is a watchlist of eye-opening expenditures, which Coburn blames on a "let them eat caviar" attitude in Washington -- at a time when "23 million of our fellow Americans do not have good jobs," Coburn notes. Here are some highlights: - Though skeptics say there's no such thing as a free cellphone or service funded by the federal government, Coburn's report shows otherwise. It estimates that taxpayers are subsidizing phone service at a cost of nearly $1.5 billion a year. Though the roots of the program can be traced back to an effort in the 1930s to make sure all Americans had access to telecommunications, it has morphed into program that provided free cell service to some 16,500,000 participants last year. - Though NASA has no plans or budget for any manned spaceflights to Mars, the agency spends about $1 million each year on developing "the Mars menu." It's an effort to come up with a variety of food that humans could eat one day on Mars. - A $325,000 grant for the development of "Robosquirrel" - a robotic rodent designed to test the interaction between rattlesnakes and squirrels. - An estimated $70 million loss for producing pennies. According to the Waste Book, "The cost to produce a penny in 2012 is more than two times its actual value." After the pennies are manufactured and sold at face value, taxpayers are left to cover the loss. - The report spotlights widespread abuse of the food stamp system - including an exotic dancer who earned more than $85,000 a year in tips, but also collected nearly $1,000 a month in food stamps while spending $9,000 during that time period on "cosmetic enhancements." - Nearly $700,000 from the National Science Foundation to a New York-based theater company so it could develop a musical about climate change and biodiversity. "The Great Immensity" opened in Kansas City this year. Along with the songs one reviewer described as sounding like "a Wikipedia entry set to music," the audience was also able to experience "flying monkey poop." In all, the 2012 Waste Book report details 100 examples totaling nearly $19 billion. Coburn acknowledges that's a drop in the bucket in contrast to the overall federal deficit, which tops $16 trillion, but he says the items are snapshots of the bigger problem. "Would you agree with Washington that these represent national priorities, or would you conclude these reflect the out-of-touch and out-of-control spending threatening to bankrupt of nation’s future?" he said.

Topic.Title: WE DESERVE BETTER LEADER. OBAMA FAILED.

Message.Msg: NASHVILLE, Tenn. — A Republican congressman from Tennessee is telling supporters he’s not a hypocrite for discussing abortion with a mistress more than a decade ago. But now he may also have to defend his right to practice medicine. Rep. Scott DesJarlais, a physician who opposes abortion rights, said in a letter that he was “deeply sorry” that supporters had to find out about the relationship with a patient that occurred while Mr. DesJarlais was separated from his first wife. But he said he used stark language about traveling to Atlanta to get an abortion try to get the woman to acknowledge that she wasn’t pregnant. “I appreciate that this was an imprudent approach to this situation and I’m not proud of it,” Mr. DesJarlais wrote in the letter. “In retrospect I should have dealt with these matters in a more diplomatic fashion. “I am not trying to justify my actions or say that I am without fault,” he said. “But I am not the hypocrite my opponents and some liberal media outlets are portraying me as.” Meanwhile, the watchdog group Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington on Monday filed a complaint with the Tennessee Department of Health arguing that Mr. DesJarlais engaged in an inappropriate sexual relationship with a patient.

Topic.Title: WE will trade over $25.00 by Friday....

Message.Msg: I think you are optimistic. Expect a big sell off after earnings, as has happened in the past. Recent 1/4 trend appears to be sell or short into earnings, buy or cover after. On the back of all of the run up to earnings, Intel has warned! No doubt, intel is for sure snapping up its own stock at these prices. Hell, we're at 2009 prices, with NOW the float down near 15%, sales up near 100%, EPS up near 35%. Risk today is far less than it was 3 years ago. Yes, the market has reacted to slow down in PC sales. Though look at the facts. - Intel now selling phone chips. - Intel now selling Tablet chips. - Intel now selling security software - Intel now selling phone chipsets - Intel now has most advanced mass production manufacturing platform on earth, some 2 years ahead of its competitors. IMO, market for this stock grossly OVER REACTED.
